description: A contact team sport originating from India, where a 'raider' enters the opposing team's half to tag as many defenders as possible and return to their own half without being tackled.
objective: Score points by tagging opponents and returning safely.
educationalBenefits: Enhances physical fitness, strategic thinking, and teamwork

description: A sport popular in Southeast Asia where players hit a rattan ball over a net using their feet, knees, chest, and head.
objective: Score points by grounding the ball on the opponent's side without using hands.
educationalBenefits: Improves agility, coordination, and cultural appreciation

description: An abstract strategy board game from China involving two players who alternately place black and white stones on a grid.
equipmentNeeded: Go board; Black and white stones
objective: Control more territory on the board than your opponent.
educationalBenefits: Enhances strategic thinking and concentration

description: A traditional Indian board game where players race their pieces around the board based on dice rolls.
equipmentNeeded: Pachisi board; Pawns; Dice or cowrie shells
objective: Be the first to get all your pieces to the home square.
educationalBenefits: Develops counting skills and strategic planning

description: A family of board games played around the world, involving moving stones or seeds around a board with pits.
objective: Capture more stones than your opponent.
educationalBenefits: Improves counting skills and strategic thinking

description: An ancient Scandinavian board game of strategy, involving a king's escape from attackers.
objective: Defenders aim to help the king escape; attackers aim to capture the king.
educationalBenefits: Enhances strategic thinking and historical appreciation

description: A two-player strategy board game similar to Western chess, popular in China.
objective: Checkmate the opponent's general (king).
educationalBenefits: Develops strategic thinking and cultural knowledge

description: A two-player strategy board game native to Japan, similar to chess but with unique rules like piece promotion.
objective: Checkmate the opponent's king.
educationalBenefits: Enhances strategic planning and cultural appreciation

description: A game originating from France where players throw hollow metal balls towards a small wooden target ball.
objective: Score points by having your boules closest to the target ball.
educationalBenefits: Develops precision and social interaction

description: An Afro-Brazilian martial art combining elements of dance, acrobatics, and music.
objective: Engage in a flow of movements with a partner, emphasizing skill and expression.
educationalBenefits: Enhances physical fitness, rhythm, and cultural understanding

description: A traditional Indian tag game where one team chases and tries to tag the members of the opposing team.
objective: Score points by tagging as many opponents as possible.
educationalBenefits: Improves physical fitness, teamwork, and strategic planning

description: A Chinese game where players keep a weighted shuttlecock in the air using their feet and body, without hands.
objective: Keep the shuttlecock in the air as long as possible.
educationalBenefits: Enhances coordination and physical fitness

description: An ancient ballgame from Mesoamerica played with a rubber ball, where players hit the ball using their hips.
objective: Keep the ball in play and score points against the opposing team.
educationalBenefits: Promotes physical fitness and cultural heritage awareness

description: A traditional New Zealand Maori game involving rhythmic passing and catching of sticks in patterns.
objective: Coordinate stick movements with partners in rhythm.
educationalBenefits: Enhances coordination and cultural appreciation

description: A traditional Ghanaian game where objects are hidden, and players race to find them upon a signal.
objective: Find the hidden object and reach the finish line first.
educationalBenefits: Develops observation skills and physical fitness

description: A Central Asian sport where horseback players try to place a goat or calf carcass in a goal.
objective: Score by placing the carcass in the goal area.
educationalBenefits: Enhances horsemanship and cultural understanding

description: A Korean children's game played with five small stones, involving various throwing and catching sequences.
equipmentNeeded: Five small stones or plastic pieces
objective: Complete a series of skillful maneuvers with the stones.
educationalBenefits: Develops fine motor skills and concentration

description: A Brazilian game where players hold one leg and try to knock off a handkerchief tucked in the opponent's belt.
objective: Capture the opponent's handkerchief while hopping on one leg.
educationalBenefits: Improves balance and coordination

description: A contact team sport originating from India, where a 'raider' enters the opposing team's half to tag as many defenders as possible and return to their own half without being tackled.
objective: Score points by tagging opponents and returning safely.
educationalBenefits: Enhances physical fitness, strategic thinking, and teamwork

objective: Capture the opponent's handkerchief while hopping on one leg.
educationalBenefits: Improves balance and coordination

description: A tile-based game originating from China, played with a set of 144 tiles based on Chinese characters and symbols.
equipmentNeeded: Mahjong tiles; Scoring sticks or chips
objective: Be the first to complete a legal hand by drawing and discarding tiles.
educationalBenefits: Enhances memory, strategic thinking, and cultural appreciation

description: A two-player abstract strategy game from West Africa, played on a 5x6 grid with stones or tokens.
equipmentNeeded: Game board (5x6 grid); 12 stones or tokens per player
objective: Align three of your stones in a row to remove an opponent's stone; reduce opponent to two stones to win.
educationalBenefits: Develops strategic planning and cultural knowledge

description: An Italian bowling game where players throw balls to get closest to a smaller target ball called the pallino.
objective: Score points by having your balls closer to the pallino than your opponent's.
educationalBenefits: Enhances precision, coordination, and social interaction

description: A lawn game where players throw wooden batons to knock down the opponent's wooden blocks (kubbs), ultimately aiming to knock over the king.
objective: Knock down all opponent's kubbs and then the king to win.
educationalBenefits: Develops coordination, strategy, and teamwork

description: A team sport played by Native American tribes, using sticks with small nets to pass a ball and score goals.
objective: Score points by getting the ball into the opponent's goal.
educationalBenefits: Promotes physical fitness and cultural heritage appreciation

description: An ancient game played by Native American tribes involving rolling a disc-shaped stone and throwing spears where they think it will stop.
objective: Predict where the stone will stop and throw your spear accordingly.
educationalBenefits: Enhances coordination, strategic thinking, and cultural understanding
